poem:
**Polish Dawn**

Wafer-thin victories shift the air  
in Warsaw's old streets, as  
the EU watches from afar,  
curious, cautious.  
  
The past rewritten  
by Nawrocki's ink;  
  
history bends,  
and echoes sound  
from Krakow to Brussels,  
where whispers of change  
linger like morning fog.  

A new day unfurls  
its hesitant wings.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Populist Nawrocki’s triumph threatens Poland’s place at Europe’s top table The victory margin of the nationalist Karol Nawrocki in Poland’s presidential elections may have been wafer-thin, but it marks a huge upheaval in the country’s political landscape whose impact will be felt not just in Warsaw but across the EU. Backed by the previous ruling conservative Law & Justice (PiS) party and, openly, by Donald Trump’s Maga movement, Nawrocki, a radical-right historian, defeated his liberal". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
